Data repositories
A home for your data
The number of data repositories keeps increasing, re3data.org currently lists more than 2000 repositories. This compilation can be browsed by subject, content type or country, and further searched by e.g. type of data access (open, restricted, embargoed, closed) or metadata standards (generic e.g. Dublin Core and/or discipline-specific).
 
Repositories are locations for depositing and sharing data, and thereby obviously also a source to find data for potential reuse. They ensure long-term availability of data, and generally provide persistent identifiers (mainly DOI) for data citation.
 
Repositories can be general (accepting a wide range of data from any scientist), institutional (also often content covering a wide range of scientific fields, but data upload contingent on institutional affiliation) or discipline-specific.
 
Discipline-specific repositories are recommended, as they provide more opportunities (but also obligations) to document data according to needs and standards of a scientific field. Data are also more likely to be discovered by other scientists working in the same or closely related fields. Various journals/publishers have lists of recommended repositories:
 
Scientific Data (Springer Nature) recommended data repositories
 
PLoS ONE (applying to all PLOS journals)
 
PeerJ Data and Materials Sharing
